thread.title: Mason Jet Lee: March draws attention to child safety crisis | The Courier-Mail
thread.title_full: Mason Jet Lee: March draws attention to child safety crisis | The Courier-Mail

title: Mason Jet Lee: March draws attention to child safety crisis | The Courier-Mail
text:
Accused ‘left to have sex’ 
A QUEENSLAND community has rallied together to demand better protection for at-risk children in the state. 
More than 200 Caboolture residents this morning marched in support of justice for Mason Jet Lee, a 21-month-old boy who last year died following horrific alleged neglect. 
The walk was organised by Act For Mason, a group founded by several Queensland mums who wanted to ensure Mason was not forgotten. 
Founding member Katherine Christensen said there was “no one who feels the loss deeper” than the people in Mason’s home town. 
She called for action from the Queensland Government to ensure the state’s children were protected. 
“Where is the sense of urgency that is needed to ensure that this doesn’t happen again?” she said. 
“When we walk for Mason it’s our collective voices saying no longer will Queensland just sit idly back and leave the protection of our kids up to those who are simply not up to the task.” media_camera Act For Mason march at Caboolture this morning. Picture: Clare Armstrong 
Opposition child safety spokeswoman Ros Bates attended the walk and addressed the crowd, calling for the Government to publish both the internal and external reviews into Mason’s death. 
“We don’t know whether the Minister (Shannon Fentiman) and her department have actually put in place policies and procedures to make sure Mason Jet Lee does not happen again, and that is just not good enough,” she said. 
Ms Bates said Mason’s community need to know what the review says and what happened to Mason. 
“Today we are walking in honour of Mason here at ground zero at Caboolture, this is where Mason came from, this is where a lot of the child safety crisis has emanated from. 
“We want to see action now, it’s been over 12 months since (Mason) was in hospital ... and we still don’t have any answers,” she said. 
After the walk, Act For Mason representatives held a tree planting ceremony in the Apex Park in honour of the toddler. media_camera Activists want to ensure the case of Mason Jet Lee is not forgotten. Most viewed
